articleContent.title: Chord: 11th in G (Shape: A)
articleContent.content:
# Chord: 11th in G (Shape: A)

## Brief Presentation
The 11th chord in the key of G played with an A shape is a rich and colorful chord that adds depth and emotion to a piece of music. It consists of the root note G, the major 3rd (B), the perfect 5th (D), the dominant 7th (F), and the 11th note (C).

## Notes and Intervals
- Root: G
- Major 3rd: B
- Perfect 5th: D
- Dominant 7th: F
- 11th note: C

## Musical Flavor and Genre
The 11th chord in G played with an A shape brings a jazzy and sophisticated flavor to music. It is commonly found in jazz, funk, and R&B genres, adding a sense of tension and release due to the inclusion of the 11th note.

## Three Songs
Here are three songs that feature the 11th chord in G (Shape: A):
1. **"So What" by Miles Davis** - This jazz classic prominently features the 11th chord in G throughout the song.
2. **"Cissy Strut" by The Meters** - This funk tune makes use of the 11th chord in G to create a groovy and rhythmic feel.
3. **"Redemption Song" by Bob Marley** - This reggae anthem incorporates the 11th chord in G to evoke a sense of positivity and hope. 

This chord adds a unique and colorful sound to these songs, showcasing its versatility in various musical styles.
